G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: This is an action by a residential tenant against her landlord for breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, §14, arising out of Defendant’s failure to provide hot water at the Premises for an extended period of time.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a719\u201321.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Brockton Division of the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§19–21 and G.L. c. 223 because the Premises are located in Brockton, Massachusetts, the acts and omissions complained of occurred in Brockton, and the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limit of this Court.

G.L. c. 223.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Brockton Division of the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§19–21 and G.L. c. 223 because the Premises are located in Brockton, Massachusetts, the acts and omissions complained of occurred in Brockton, and the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limit of this Court.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: As a residential landlord in Massachusetts, Defendant is required by statute and regulation to provide hot water and to maintain the Premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.

105 C.M.R. 410.190\u2013410.200.proposition: The State Sanitary Code provides that the owner shall provide and maintain facilities for heating water and that hot water must be supplied in quantities and at temperatures specified by regulation.

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 201–02 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a lack of hot water is a serious violation of the State Sanitary Code and materially affects the habitability of residential premises.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly treats loss of heat and hot water as “material breaches of the warranty of habitability,” and ties the scope of that warranty to compliance with the State Sanitary Code. It further states that a dwelling with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable, and specifically notes that the Code puts the landlord on notice it must supply adequate heat and hot water. This squarely supports the idea that lack of hot water is a serious Sanitary Code violation that materially affects habitability.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Superior Court judge found…[t]he losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability… ‘[T]he essential objective of the leasing transaction is to provide a dwelling suitable for habitation.’… A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable… The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. State Sanitary Code, Art. II, Regulations 5, 6 (1969)… The landlord can have no reasonable grounds to believe that noncompliance will be acceptable.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–200 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a lack of hot water is a serious violation of the State Sanitary Code and materially affects the habitability of residential premises.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The excerpt is from a concurrence/dissent and does not single out hot water, but it repeatedly describes State Sanitary Code violations as conditions that may ‘endanger or materially impair the health or safety and the well-being’ of tenants and ‘render the apartment uninhabitable.’ Under Massachusetts law after Hemingway, serious State Sanitary Code violations—including lack of hot water—are treated as materially affecting habitability. While this passage does not expressly mention hot water, it does recognize that serious sanitary code violations materially affect habitability, which is the core of the proposition.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The tenants defend principally on the following grounds… that the Housing Inspection Department had inspected defendant’s apartment… and found said apartment to be in violation of the State Sanitary Code and that the conditions… were such that ‘said violations may endanger or materially impair the health or safety and the well being of any tenant therein…;’ and that said violations and conditions… render the apartment uninhabitable….”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s liability for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment does not depend on the landlord’s good faith or intent but rather on whether the landlord’s acts or omissions substantially interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court expressly discusses the covenant/statutory right of quiet enjoyment and explains that, under both the common law background and G.L. c. 186, § 14, liability does not turn on the landlord’s specific intent but on whether the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s conduct is interference with the tenant’s rights. It states that earlier intent-focused cases have been superseded by a standard based on the landlord’s conduct and its consequences. This aligns with the proposition that liability depends on substantial interference rather than good faith or intent.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “Although early cases applying the covenant of quiet enjoyment required intent on the part of the landlord, e.g., Katz v. Duffy, 261 Mass. 149 (1927), more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights. Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381-383 (1942). Shindler v. Milden, 282 Mass. 32, 33 (1933). See also Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716 (1977). … In Blackett, … we held that ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions’ determine whether he has violated the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s liability for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment does not depend on the landlord’s good faith or intent but rather on whether the landlord’s acts or omissions substantially interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that analysis of a quiet enjoyment claim looks to the landlord’s conduct rather than the landlord’s intentions, and that liability can arise where the interference is the “natural and probable consequence” of what the landlord did or failed to do. The court focuses on whether the landlord’s omissions permitted conditions that “seriously interfere” with the tenancy, not on the landlord’s good faith or subjective intent, directly matching the proposition.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy… In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, *we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions*. Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716 (1977). Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.proposition: A landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment where there is a serious and persistent deficiency in an essential service, such as heat or hot water, that substantially impairs the character and value of the leased premises.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.support_reasoning: The opinion itself deals with noise from a bar rather than lack of heat or hot water, but in explaining constructive eviction and breach of quiet enjoyment, the court expressly cites Charles E. Burt v. Seven Grand Corp. (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services) and other cases as examples of breaches where serious and persistent deficiencies in essential services substantially impaired habitability. Thus, Blackett affirms that such service failures can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even though that is not the specific fact pattern before the court.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services). Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381 (1942) (intrusions of smoke and soot over a substantial period of time due to a defective boiler).

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: Defendant’s failure to restore hot water over this extended period constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 111, §§127A–127L and 105 C.M.R. 410.190–410.200, and such State Sanitary Code violations are recognized as grounds for liability for breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, §14.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a violation of the lead paint statute, G.L. c. 111, §§190–199, automatically constitutes a violation of the quiet enjoyment statute, G.L. c. 186, §14. It holds that such a statutory violation alone does not suffice and that at least negligent conduct with notice is required; it does not address G.L. c. 111, §§127A–127L or the cited State Sanitary Code hot-water provisions, nor does it state that any State Sanitary Code violation is per se a basis for §14 liability. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition claimed about hot water and §§127A–127L/105 C.M.R. 410.190–410.200.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 787–89 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that persistent conditions depriving tenants of essential services, including heat and hot water, constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The court explicitly holds that the landlord’s failure to correct numerous code violations, specifically including inadequate heat and hot water, constituted a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14—the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. It further grounds this conclusion in prior Massachusetts decisions treating such persistent defective conditions as impairing the value of the premises and thus breaching quiet enjoyment. This directly supports the proposition that persistent loss of essential services like heat and hot water can amount to a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations in the apartment leased by Thomas. It was wholly foreseeable (in fact, it was inevitable) that the failure adequately to correct these violations, which included inadequate heat and hot water and a serious infestation of vermin, would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place for Thomas and her family. On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744, 748–50 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that persistent conditions depriving tenants of essential services, including heat and hot water, constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment only in general terms and focuses on whether the particular defects in Casey’s apartment, which did not involve loss of essential services like heat or hot water, constituted a breach. The court ultimately finds no breach and does not hold or reiterate that persistent deprivation of essential services (such as heat and hot water) constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment; those examples appear only in a footnote describing warranty-of-habitability cases, not as a repeated Massachusetts rule about quiet enjoyment. Thus, the case does not actually support the specific proposition claimed.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “Casey counterclaimed that York breached her covenant of quiet enjoyment. Similar to the warranty of habitability, during the rental of any residential premises, there exists an implied covenant and a statutory right of quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); G. L. c. 186, § 14. We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Authy., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994).”
